10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-012-0349-y34910.1007/s10870-012-0349-yOriginal PaperA New Coordination Polymer of Zn(II)-btc (H3btc = Benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) with Protonated Acridine: Synthesis, Crystal Structure and Spectroscopic PropertiesPeiWenbo1HanZhangang1XieJingli12cZouYang3RenXiao-Ming4grid.1002.30000000419367857School of ChemistryMonash University3800ClaytonVICAustraliagrid.8756.c000000012193314XWestCHEM, School of ChemistryThe University of GlasgowUniversity AvenueG12 8QQGlasgowUKgrid.413273.00000000105748737Department of ChemistryZhejiang Sci-Tech UniversityXiasha Campus310018HangzhouPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.412022.70000000093895210College of ScienceNanjing University of Technology210009NanjingPeople’s Republic of China+44-0-141-330-4888jingli.xie@monash.edu178201210201242101007101348201217820114820121782012© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20122012Abstract

A new Zn(II)-btc coordination polymer 1 (H3btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) containing protonated acridines was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction at 165 °C for 3 days and characterized by FT-IR, UV–Vis, Fluorescence, TGA measurements and single-crystal/powder X-ray crystallography. The crystallographic data for 1: monoclinic, P21/n, a = 11.0100(5), b = 16.7104(7), c = 11.7492(5) Å, β = 98.735(2), V = 2136.56(16) Å3, Z = 4, T = 130(2) K, Dc = 1.572 g cm−3, F(000) = 1036, μ(Mo Kα) = 1.205 mm−1, GOF = 1.005. R1 = 0.0427, wR2 = 0.1410 [I > 2σ(I)]. Structural analysis also revealed that the btc3− ligands bridge four-coordinate Zn(II) centres to form a 2-D grid-like layer network on the bc plane. The protonated acridines fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers and combine the 2-D layers to generate a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular framework through the hydrogen bondings and π···π packing interactions. The fluorescence investigation disclosed that 1 shows multiband emissions over a wide range.

Graphical Abstract

A non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular framework, built from Zn(II) ions and benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate ligands, encapsulates the protonated acridines and exhibits multiband fluorescence emissions over a wide range.

Considerable efforts have been undertaken to generate supramolecular coordination polymers over the past decades, owing to their potential application in the field of asymmetric catalysis [1], chiral separations [2], ion exchange [3], adsorption–desorption [4], gas storage [5–7], non-linear optics [8] and molecular magnetism [9, 10]. Generally, these compounds are prepared by conventional solution methods under ambient experimental conditions. In recent years, hydro- and/or solvo-thermal techniques, performed with high temperature and pressure, have received great attention because they could extend the range of structural types of various metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) in a feasible way [11, 12]. Those coordination polymers contain metal centers that are interconnected by multitopic organic ligands to achieve fascinating topological structures [13]. Although extremely well-studied for decades, better understanding of metal–ligand interactions that can reliably construct intriguing topologies and architectures with potential application is still highly desirable.

The multidentate benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate ligand has been employed to connect cationic metal nodes in order to construct a wide variety of novel network structures [14, 15]. In 1999, Williams and coworkers reported their pioneering work on a highly porous metal coordination polymer [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3]n (where TMA is benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate), which assemble a three-dimensional (3-D) system containing channels with a pore size of 1 nm and the accessible porosity of around 40 % in the solid state. Unlike zeolites, the channel linings could be chemically functionalized [16]. Moreover, co-ligands have been introduced for the construction of coordination polymers because they provide more potential coordination sites for metal centers, to achieve new topologies and architectures. Feng and coworkers [17] used 4,4′-bipyridine and piperazine as the co-ligands and built interpenetrating networks of pure zinc clusters. In 2005, Yaghi and coworkers demonstrated the effective secondary building units (SBUs) in the synthesis of MOFs with rigid and porous architectures by using polytopic carboxylates as co-ligands [18]. It is found that co-ligands may play an important role during the self-assembly process [19]. Among them, the incorporation of Zn(II) and Cd(II) in the supramolecular architectures is of great interest due to their appealing structures and photoluminescent properties. These coordination polymers display a variety of structural motifs, such as one-dimensional (1-D) helical ribbon or molecular zippers, 2-D molecular squares or triangular grids, and penetrating and non-penetrating 3-D networks [20–23].

In our previous work, we prepared three Cd(II) coordination polymers with different networks, which are affected by co-ligands [19]. In this paper, we carried out hydrothermal reaction of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O, benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3btc) with acridine as the co-ligand, allowing the formation of novel coordination polymer with intriguing properties.

ExperimentalChemicals and Reagents

All reagents and chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Coordination Compound <bold>1</bold>

The mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (82.3 mg, 0.375 mmol), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (52.5 mg, 0.250 mmol), acridine (44.8 mg, 0.250 mmol) and distilled water (15.0 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 20 min and transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave (internal volume: 23.0 mL). The sealed autoclave was heated up at 165 °C under autogenous pressure for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Orange-red block-like crystals of 1 were collected in a total yield of 65.0 % based on Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O source. The solid sample was washed by distilled water and isolated by filtration. PXRD pattern of 1 was shown in Fig. 1, from which it could be observed that the experimental pattern for the PXRD measurement match well with the simulated pattern.

Physical Measurements

The FT-IR spectrum in the range 4,000–400 cm−1 was recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR Spectrometer. UV–Vis spectrum was recorded on UV-1650 PC spectrophotometer (double cell mode, baseline correction was performed a wavelength scan from 800 to 200 nm). Fluorescence measurements were performed on Varian Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker-AXSr D8 Advance (Super speed) diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation at room temperature. TGA experiment was performed with a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal in the 20–800 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere, and the polycrystalline samples were placed in a porcelain crucible.

Single Crystal X-Ray Crystallography

Crystallographic data, details of the data collection and refinement were summarized in Table 1. Crystal structure was solved using direct methods (SHELXTL V5.1 [24]) from single-crystal data collected at 130 K on a Bruker SMART/CCD area detector diffractometer fitted with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and a graphite monochromator. Structure refinements were performed using the SHELX97 [25] program, which used a full-matrix least-squares refinement based on F2. Absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS program [26].

Results and DiscussionDescription of Crystal Structure

As shown in Fig. 2, the Zn(II) centre is four-coordinated with oxygen atoms, three of them from carboxyl groups of different btc3− anions and one of them from H2O molecule, showing a tetrahedron geometry of {ZnO4} with the corresponding bond lengths to be Zn(1)–O(1) = 1.9576(19) Å, Zn(1)–O(3) = 1.950(2) Å, Zn(1)–O(5) = 1.933(2) Å and Zn(1)–O(7) = 1.936(2) Å. The protonated acridine acts as a countercation in the crystal structure. Besides, there are two lattice H2O molecules in the asymmetric unit of 1. So each Zn(II) centre is surrounded by three carboxyl groups from three different btc3− ligands and vice versa, from which it extend the 2-D grid-like layer network into a 4.62 topological feature on the bc plane (Fig. 3b). The grid-like network has a parallel packing with the Zn···Zn distance of 11.7492(7) Å. The protonated acridines fill up the 1-D cavities formed between adjacent layers (see Fig. 3). As shown in Fig. 4, there exists strong hydrogen bonding interactions (the geometric parameters of hydrogen bonds are listed in Table 2) as well as face-to-face π···π interactions between the phenyl rings of the btc3− anions and protonated acridines, with the distance is around 3.61 Å between ring centroids for the phenyl rings of the btc3− anions and the aromatic ring containing C1, C2, C10, C11, C12 and C13 atoms of the protonated acridines, 3.49 Å for the phenyl rings of the btc3− anions and the aromatic ring containing N1, C2, C3, C8, C9, C10 atoms of the protonated acridines. These weak interactions combine the 2-D layers to form a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network.

IR Spectrum

In the FT-IR spectrum of 1, a broad but strong band in the range of 3,460–2,800 cm−1 is attributed to νN–H and νC–H of protonated acridine and aromatic ring of btc3− as well as νO–H of H2O molecule; three strong bands in the range of 1,520–1,750 cm−1 as well as the strong bands around 1,360 cm−1 are ascribed to the stretching vibrations of C=O and the skeleton of aromatic ring of the btc3− ligand; The νZn–O band appears at 745 cm−1.

Thermal Analysis

TGA analysis was carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1. As illustrated in Fig. 5, the first thermal decomposition stage occurred in the range of 76–130 °C with a corresponding weight loss 10.31 %, which was assigned to two lattice water and one coordinating water molecules (calc. 10.69 %). The second weight loss was 35.20 % in the temperature range of 200–350 °C and was consistent with the decomposition of protonated acridines (calc. 35.43 %). The third decomposition stage continued with a weight loss of 30 % up to 500 °C. This process suggested the thermal decomposition of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate.

UV–Vis Spectrum

The UV–Vis spectrum of 1 in DMSO (c = 5 × 10−5 mol L−1) is shown in Fig. 6, which exhibits a series of bands in the UV range of 250–400 nm. A strong absorbance band centred at 260 nm with high molar extinction coefficient could be attributed to π–π* type transition within protonated acridines. A series of bands centered at 347, 357, 379 and 397 nm could be attributed to the π→π* transitions within the btc3− ligands [27]. The maxima of absorption wavelengths with the molar extinction coefficients as well as the assignment of the absorption spectra are summarized in Table 3.

Fluorescence Emission

A number of polynuclear d10 transition metal complexes, such as Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers, exhibit interesting luminescence properties [28–30]. Fluorescent investigation of 1 was carried out in the solution and the solid phase at room temperature. As illustrated in Fig. 7a, upon a single-wavelength photo-excitation at 274 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of 1 in the solution phase shows three overlapping emission bands in the range of 380–650 nm (peak at 407, 431 and 455 nm), which is similar to the emission property of original acridine ligand in Fig. 7b. So the multiband emission of 1 could be assigned to the emission of the pure organic component [19]. Study of the photoluminescence properties of 1 in the solid state at room temperature is shown in Fig. 7c. Excitation at λex = 270 nm leads to a broad emission from 350 to 500 nm compared with the emission of 1 in the solution phase. This is presumably due to the combination of ion electronic state induced by strong face-to-face π···π interactions between protonated cations and btc3− ligands as well as strong hydrogen bonding interactions in the solid phase [31, 32]. The multiband emissions are expected to be useful in designing luminescent devices.

Conclusions

In summary, we have synthesized a new Zn(II) coordination polymer under hydrothermal reaction with non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network. The Zn(II) centre adopts a four-coordinated mode and is bound by four oxygen atoms. The btc3− ligands bridge metal centres into a 2-D grid-like layer network. The protonated acridines act as counter cations and fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers, and further combine the layers to a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network. Fluorescent investigations disclosed that multiband emissions in a wide region for 1 are mainly from the organic components.

The protonated acridine acts as a countercation in the crystal structure. Besides, there are two lattice H2O molecules in the asymmetric unit of 1. So each Zn(II) centre is surrounded by three carboxyl groups from three different btc3- ligands and vice versa, from which it extend the 2-D grid-like layer network into a 4.62 topological feature on the bc plane (Fig. 3b). The grid-like network has a parallel packing with the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 11.7492(7) Å. The protonated acridines fill up the 1-D cavities formed between adjacent layers (see Fig. 3). As shown in Fig. 4, there exists strong hydrogen bonding interactions (the geometric parameters of hydrogen bonds are listed in Table 2) as well as face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the phenyl rings of the btc3- anions and protonated acridines, with the distance is around 3.61 Å between ring centroids for the phenyl rings of the btc3- anions and the aromatic ring containing C1, C2, C10, C11, C12 and C13 atoms of the protonated acridines, 3.49 Å for the phenyl rings of the btc3- anions and the aromatic ring containing N1, C2, C3, C8, C9, C10 atoms of the protonated acridines. These weak interactions combine the 2-D layers to form a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network.IR SpectrumIn the FT-IR spectrum of 1, a broad but strong band in the range of 3,460-2,800 cm-1 is attributed to νN-H and νC-H of protonated acridine and aromatic ring of btc3- as well as νO-H of H2O molecule; three strong bands in the range of 1,520-1,750 cm-1 as well as the strong bands around 1,360 cm-1 are ascribed to the stretching vibrations of C=O and the skeleton of aromatic ring of the btc3- ligand; The νZn-O band appears at 745 cm-1.Thermal AnalysisTGA analysis was carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1. As illustrated in Fig. 5, the first thermal decomposition stage occurred in the range of 76-130 °C with a corresponding weight loss 10.31 %, which was assigned to two lattice water and one coordinating water molecules (calc. 10.69 %). The second weight loss was 35.20 % in the temperature range of 200-350 °C and was consistent with the decomposition of protonated acridines (calc. 35.43 %). The third decomposition stage continued with a weight loss of 30 % up to 500 °C. This process suggested the thermal decomposition of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate.UV-Vis SpectrumThe UV-Vis spectrum of 1 in DMSO (c = 5 × 10-5 mol L-1) is shown in Fig. 6, which exhibits a series of bands in the UV range of 250-400 nm. A strong absorbance band centred at 260 nm with high molar extinction coefficient could be attributed to π-π* type transition within protonated acridines. A series of bands centered at 347, 357, 379 and 397 nm could be attributed to the π→π* transitions within the btc3- ligands [27]. The maxima of absorption wavelengths with the molar extinction coefficients as well as the assignment of the absorption spectra are summarized in Table 3.Fluorescence EmissionA number of polynuclear d10 transition metal complexes, such as Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers, exhibit interesting luminescence properties [28-30]. Fluorescent investigation of 1 was carried out in the solution and the solid phase at room temperature. As illustrated in Fig. 7a, upon a single-wavelength photo-excitation at 274 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of 1 in the solution phase shows three overlapping emission bands in the range of 380-650 nm (peak at 407, 431 and 455 nm), which is similar to the emission property of original acridine ligand in Fig. 7b. So the multiband emission of 1 could be assigned to the emission of the pure organic component [19]. Study of the photoluminescence properties of 1 in the solid state at room temperature is shown in Fig. 7c. Excitation at λex = 270 nm leads to a broad emission from 350 to 500 nm compared with the emission of 1 in the solution phase. This is presumably due to the combination of ion electronic state induced by strong face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between protonated cations and btc3- ligands as well as strong hydrogen bonding interactions in the solid phase [31, 32]. The multiband emissions are expected to be useful in designing luminescent devices.ConclusionsIn summary, we have synthesized a new Zn(II) coordination polymer under hydrothermal reaction with non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network. The Zn(II) centre adopts a four-coordinated mode and is bound by four oxygen atoms. The btc3- ligands bridge metal centres into a 2-D grid-like layer network. The protonated acridines act as counter cations and fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers, and further combine the layers to a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network. Fluorescent investigations disclosed that multiband emissions in a wide region for 1 are mainly from the organic components.Supplementary MaterialCCDC-808334 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. elements.content: A new Zn(II)-btc coordination polymer 1 (H3btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) containing protonated acridines was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction at 165 °C for 3 days and characterized by FT-IR, UV–Vis, Fluorescence, TGA measurements and single-crystal/powder X-ray crystallography. The crystallographic data for 1: monoclinic, P21/n, a = 11.0100(5), b = 16.7104(7), c = 11.7492(5) Å, β = 98.735(2), V = 2136.56(16) Å3, Z = 4, T = 130(2) K, Dc = 1.572 g cm−3, F(000) = 1036, μ(Mo Kα) = 1.205 mm−1, GOF = 1.005. R1 = 0.0427, wR2 = 0.1410 [I > 2σ(I)]. Structural analysis also revealed that the btc3− ligands bridge four-coordinate Zn(II) centres to form a 2-D grid-like layer network on the bc plane. The protonated acridines fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers and combine the 2-D layers to generate a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular framework through the hydrogen bondings and π···π packing interactions. The fluorescence investigation disclosed that 1 shows multiband emissions over a wide range.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new Zn(II)-btc coordination polymer 1 (H3btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) containing protonated acridines was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction at 165 °C for 3 days and characterized by FT-IR, UV-Vis, Fluorescence, TGA measurements and single-crystal/powder X-ray crystallography. The crystallographic data for 1: monoclinic, P21/n, a = 11.0100(5), b = 16.7104(7), c = 11.7492(5) Å, β = 98.735(2), V = 2136.56(16) Å3, Z = 4, T = 130(2) K, Dc = 1.572 g cm-3, F(000) = 1036, μ(Mo Kα) = 1.205 mm-1, GOF = 1.005. R1 = 0.0427, wR2 = 0.1410 [I > 2σ(I)]. Structural analysis also revealed that the btc3- ligands bridge four-coordinate Zn(II) centres to form a 2-D grid-like layer network on the bc plane. The protonated acridines fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers and combine the 2-D layers to generate a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular framework through the hydrogen bondings and π⋅⋅⋅π packing interactions. The fluorescence investigation disclosed that 1 shows multiband emissions over a wide range.

elements.content: A non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular framework, built from Zn(II) ions and benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate ligands, encapsulates the protonated acridines and exhibits multiband fluorescence emissions over a wide range.
elements.clean_text:
Graphical Abstract

A non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular framework, built from Zn(II) ions and benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate ligands, encapsulates the protonated acridines and exhibits multiband fluorescence emissions over a wide range.

elements.content: Considerable efforts have been undertaken to generate supramolecular coordination polymers over the past decades, owing to their potential application in the field of asymmetric catalysis [1], chiral separations [2], ion exchange [3], adsorption–desorption [4], gas storage [5–7], non-linear optics [8] and molecular magnetism [9, 10]. Generally, these compounds are prepared by conventional solution methods under ambient experimental conditions. In recent years, hydro- and/or solvo-thermal techniques, performed with high temperature and pressure, have received great attention because they could extend the range of structural types of various metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) in a feasible way [11, 12]. Those coordination polymers contain metal centers that are interconnected by multitopic organic ligands to achieve fascinating topological structures [13]. Although extremely well-studied for decades, better understanding of metal–ligand interactions that can reliably construct intriguing topologies and architectures with potential application is still highly desirable.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Considerable efforts have been undertaken to generate supramolecular coordination polymers over the past decades, owing to their potential application in the field of asymmetric catalysis [1], chiral separations [2], ion exchange [3], adsorption-desorption [4], gas storage [5-7], non-linear optics [8] and molecular magnetism [9, 10]. Generally, these compounds are prepared by conventional solution methods under ambient experimental conditions. In recent years, hydro- and/or solvo-thermal techniques, performed with high temperature and pressure, have received great attention because they could extend the range of structural types of various metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) in a feasible way [11, 12]. Those coordination polymers contain metal centers that are interconnected by multitopic organic ligands to achieve fascinating topological structures [13]. Although extremely well-studied for decades, better understanding of metal-ligand interactions that can reliably construct intriguing topologies and architectures with potential application is still highly desirable.

elements.content: The multidentate benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate ligand has been employed to connect cationic metal nodes in order to construct a wide variety of novel network structures [14, 15]. In 1999, Williams and coworkers reported their pioneering work on a highly porous metal coordination polymer [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3]n (where TMA is benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate), which assemble a three-dimensional (3-D) system containing channels with a pore size of 1 nm and the accessible porosity of around 40 % in the solid state. Unlike zeolites, the channel linings could be chemically functionalized [16]. Moreover, co-ligands have been introduced for the construction of coordination polymers because they provide more potential coordination sites for metal centers, to achieve new topologies and architectures. Feng and coworkers [17] used 4,4′-bipyridine and piperazine as the co-ligands and built interpenetrating networks of pure zinc clusters. In 2005, Yaghi and coworkers demonstrated the effective secondary building units (SBUs) in the synthesis of MOFs with rigid and porous architectures by using polytopic carboxylates as co-ligands [18]. It is found that co-ligands may play an important role during the self-assembly process [19]. Among them, the incorporation of Zn(II) and Cd(II) in the supramolecular architectures is of great interest due to their appealing structures and photoluminescent properties. These coordination polymers display a variety of structural motifs, such as one-dimensional (1-D) helical ribbon or molecular zippers, 2-D molecular squares or triangular grids, and penetrating and non-penetrating 3-D networks [20–23].

elements.content: In our previous work, we prepared three Cd(II) coordination polymers with different networks, which are affected by co-ligands [19]. In this paper, we carried out hydrothermal reaction of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O, benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3btc) with acridine as the co-ligand, allowing the formation of novel coordination polymer with intriguing properties.

elements.content:
All reagents and chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Coordination Compound <bold>1</bold>

The mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (82.3 mg, 0.375 mmol), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (52.5 mg, 0.250 mmol), acridine (44.8 mg, 0.250 mmol) and distilled water (15.0 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 20 min and transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave (internal volume: 23.0 mL). The sealed autoclave was heated up at 165 °C under autogenous pressure for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Orange-red block-like crystals of 1 were collected in a total yield of 65.0 % based on Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O source. The solid sample was washed by distilled water and isolated by filtration. PXRD pattern of 1 was shown in Fig. 1, from which it could be observed that the experimental pattern for the PXRD measurement match well with the simulated pattern.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Chemicals and Reagents

All reagents and chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Coordination Compound 1

The mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (82.3 mg, 0.375 mmol), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (52.5 mg, 0.250 mmol), acridine (44.8 mg, 0.250 mmol) and distilled water (15.0 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 20 min and transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave (internal volume: 23.0 mL). The sealed autoclave was heated up at 165 °C under autogenous pressure for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Orange-red block-like crystals of 1 were collected in a total yield of 65.0 % based on Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O source. The solid sample was washed by distilled water and isolated by filtration. PXRD pattern of 1 was shown in Fig. 1, from which it could be observed that the experimental pattern for the PXRD measurement match well with the simulated pattern.

elements.content: The FT-IR spectrum in the range 4,000–400 cm−1 was recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR Spectrometer. UV–Vis spectrum was recorded on UV-1650 PC spectrophotometer (double cell mode, baseline correction was performed a wavelength scan from 800 to 200 nm). Fluorescence measurements were performed on Varian Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker-AXSr D8 Advance (Super speed) diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation at room temperature. TGA experiment was performed with a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal in the 20–800 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere, and the polycrystalline samples were placed in a porcelain crucible.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

The FT-IR spectrum in the range 4,000-400 cm-1 was recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR Spectrometer. UV-Vis spectrum was recorded on UV-1650 PC spectrophotometer (double cell mode, baseline correction was performed a wavelength scan from 800 to 200 nm). Fluorescence measurements were performed on Varian Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker-AXSr D8 Advance (Super speed) diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation at room temperature. TGA experiment was performed with a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal in the 20-800 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere, and the polycrystalline samples were placed in a porcelain crucible.

elements.content: Crystallographic data, details of the data collection and refinement were summarized in Table 1. Crystal structure was solved using direct methods (SHELXTL V5.1 [24]) from single-crystal data collected at 130 K on a Bruker SMART/CCD area detector diffractometer fitted with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and a graphite monochromator. Structure refinements were performed using the SHELX97 [25] program, which used a full-matrix least-squares refinement based on F2. Absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS program [26].

Structure refinements were performed using the SHELX97 [25] program, which used a full-matrix least-squares refinement based on F2. Absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS program [26].

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structure

As shown in Fig. 2, the Zn(II) centre is four-coordinated with oxygen atoms, three of them from carboxyl groups of different btc3- anions and one of them from H2O molecule, showing a tetrahedron geometry of {ZnO4} with the corresponding bond lengths to be Zn(1)-O(1) = 1.9576(19) Å, Zn(1)-O(3) = 1.950(2) Å, Zn(1)-O(5) = 1.933(2) Å and Zn(1)-O(7) = 1.936(2) Å. The protonated acridine acts as a countercation in the crystal structure. Besides, there are two lattice H2O molecules in the asymmetric unit of 1. So each Zn(II) centre is surrounded by three carboxyl groups from three different btc3- ligands and vice versa, from which it extend the 2-D grid-like layer network into a 4.62 topological feature on the bc plane (Fig. 3b). The grid-like network has a parallel packing with the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 11.7492(7) Å. The protonated acridines fill up the 1-D cavities formed between adjacent layers (see Fig. 3). As shown in Fig. 4, there exists strong hydrogen bonding interactions (the geometric parameters of hydrogen bonds are listed in Table 2) as well as face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the phenyl rings of the btc3- anions and protonated acridines, with the distance is around 3.61 Å between ring centroids for the phenyl rings of the btc3- anions and the aromatic ring containing C1, C2, C10, C11, C12 and C13 atoms of the protonated acridines, 3.49 Å for the phenyl rings of the btc3- anions and the aromatic ring containing N1, C2, C3, C8, C9, C10 atoms of the protonated acridines. These weak interactions combine the 2-D layers to form a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network.

A number of polynuclear d10 transition metal complexes, such as Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers, exhibit interesting luminescence properties [28–30]. Fluorescent investigation of 1 was carried out in the solution and the solid phase at room temperature. As illustrated in Fig. 7a, upon a single-wavelength photo-excitation at 274 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of 1 in the solution phase shows three overlapping emission bands in the range of 380–650 nm (peak at 407, 431 and 455 nm), which is similar to the emission property of original acridine ligand in Fig. 7b. So the multiband emission of 1 could be assigned to the emission of the pure organic component [19]. Study of the photoluminescence properties of 1 in the solid state at room temperature is shown in Fig. 7c. Excitation at λex = 270 nm leads to a broad emission from 350 to 500 nm compared with the emission of 1 in the solution phase. This is presumably due to the combination of ion electronic state induced by strong face-to-face π···π interactions between protonated cations and btc3− ligands as well as strong hydrogen bonding interactions in the solid phase [31, 32]. The multiband emissions are expected to be useful in designing luminescent devices.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized a new Zn(II) coordination polymer under hydrothermal reaction with non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network. The Zn(II) centre adopts a four-coordinated mode and is bound by four oxygen atoms. The btc3− ligands bridge metal centres into a 2-D grid-like layer network. The protonated acridines act as counter cations and fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers, and further combine the layers to a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network. Fluorescent investigations disclosed that multiband emissions in a wide region for 1 are mainly from the organic components.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have synthesized a new Zn(II) coordination polymer under hydrothermal reaction with non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network. The Zn(II) centre adopts a four-coordinated mode and is bound by four oxygen atoms. The btc3- ligands bridge metal centres into a 2-D grid-like layer network. The protonated acridines act as counter cations and fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers, and further combine the layers to a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular network. Fluorescent investigations disclosed that multiband emissions in a wide region for 1 are mainly from the organic components.

All reagents and chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Coordination Compound <bold>1</bold>

The mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (82.3 mg, 0.375 mmol), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (52.5 mg, 0.250 mmol), acridine (44.8 mg, 0.250 mmol) and distilled water (15.0 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 20 min and transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave (internal volume: 23.0 mL). The sealed autoclave was heated up at 165 °C under autogenous pressure for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Orange-red block-like crystals of 1 were collected in a total yield of 65.0 % based on Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O source. The solid sample was washed by distilled water and isolated by filtration. PXRD pattern of 1 was shown in Fig. 1, from which it could be observed that the experimental pattern for the PXRD measurement match well with the simulated pattern.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Chemicals and Reagents

All reagents and chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Coordination Compound 1

The mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (82.3 mg, 0.375 mmol), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (52.5 mg, 0.250 mmol), acridine (44.8 mg, 0.250 mmol) and distilled water (15.0 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 20 min and transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave (internal volume: 23.0 mL). The sealed autoclave was heated up at 165 °C under autogenous pressure for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. Orange-red block-like crystals of 1 were collected in a total yield of 65.0 % based on Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O source. The solid sample was washed by distilled water and isolated by filtration. PXRD pattern of 1 was shown in Fig. 1, from which it could be observed that the experimental pattern for the PXRD measurement match well with the simulated pattern.

cln_elements.content:
A new Zn(II)-btc coordination polymer 1 (H3btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid) containing protonated acridines was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction at 165 °C for 3 days and characterized by FT-IR, UV–Vis, Fluorescence, TGA measurements and single-crystal/powder X-ray crystallography. The crystallographic data for 1: monoclinic, P21/n, a = 11.0100(5), b = 16.7104(7), c = 11.7492(5) Å, β = 98.735(2), V = 2136.56(16) Å3, Z = 4, T = 130(2) K, Dc = 1.572 g cm−3, F(000) = 1036, μ(Mo Kα) = 1.205 mm−1, GOF = 1.005. R1 = 0.0427, wR2 = 0.1410 [I > 2σ(I)]. Structural analysis also revealed that the btc3− ligands bridge four-coordinate Zn(II) centres to form a 2-D grid-like layer network on the bc plane. The protonated acridines fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers and combine the 2-D layers to generate a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular framework through the hydrogen bondings and π···π packing interactions. The fluorescence investigation disclosed that 1 shows multiband emissions over a wide range.

Thermal Analysis

TGA analysis was carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1. As illustrated in Fig. 5, the first thermal decomposition stage occurred in the range of 76–130 °C with a corresponding weight loss 10.31 %, which was assigned to two lattice water and one coordinating water molecules (calc. 10.69 %). The second weight loss was 35.20 % in the temperature range of 200–350 °C and was consistent with the decomposition of protonated acridines (calc. 35.43 %). The third decomposition stage continued with a weight loss of 30 % up to 500 °C. This process suggested the thermal decomposition of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate.

UV–Vis Spectrum

The UV–Vis spectrum of 1 in DMSO (c = 5 × 10−5 mol L−1) is shown in Fig. 6, which exhibits a series of bands in the UV range of 250–400 nm. A strong absorbance band centred at 260 nm with high molar extinction coefficient could be attributed to π–π* type transition within protonated acridines. A series of bands centered at 347, 357, 379 and 397 nm could be attributed to the π→π* transitions within the btc3− ligands [27]. The maxima of absorption wavelengths with the molar extinction coefficients as well as the assignment of the absorption spectra are summarized in Table 3.

Fluorescence Emission

A number of polynuclear d10 transition metal complexes, such as Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers, exhibit interesting luminescence properties [28–30]. Fluorescent investigation of 1 was carried out in the solution and the solid phase at room temperature. As illustrated in Fig. 7a, upon a single-wavelength photo-excitation at 274 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of 1 in the solution phase shows three overlapping emission bands in the range of 380–650 nm (peak at 407, 431 and 455 nm), which is similar to the emission property of original acridine ligand in Fig. 7b. So the multiband emission of 1 could be assigned to the emission of the pure organic component [19]. Study of the photoluminescence properties of 1 in the solid state at room temperature is shown in Fig. 7c. Excitation at λex = 270 nm leads to a broad emission from 350 to 500 nm compared with the emission of 1 in the solution phase. This is presumably due to the combination of ion electronic state induced by strong face-to-face π···π interactions between protonated cations and btc3− ligands as well as strong hydrogen bonding interactions in the solid phase [31, 32]. The multiband emissions are expected to be useful in designing luminescent devices.

The crystallographic data for 1: monoclinic, P21/n, a = 11.0100(5), b = 16.7104(7), c = 11.7492(5) Å, β = 98.735(2), V = 2136.56(16) Å3, Z = 4, T = 130(2) K, Dc = 1.572 g cm-3, F(000) = 1036, μ(Mo Kα) = 1.205 mm-1, GOF = 1.005. R1 = 0.0427, wR2 = 0.1410 [I > 2σ(I)]. Structural analysis also revealed that the btc3- ligands bridge four-coordinate Zn(II) centres to form a 2-D grid-like layer network on the bc plane. The protonated acridines fill up the cavities formed between adjacent layers and combine the 2-D layers to generate a non-interpenetrating 3-D supramolecular framework through the hydrogen bondings and π⋅⋅⋅π packing interactions. The fluorescence investigation disclosed that 1 shows multiband emissions over a wide range.

As illustrated in Fig. 5, the first thermal decomposition stage occurred in the range of 76-130 °C with a corresponding weight loss 10.31 %, which was assigned to two lattice water and one coordinating water molecules (calc. 10.69 %). The second weight loss was 35.20 % in the temperature range of 200-350 °C and was consistent with the decomposition of protonated acridines (calc. 35.43 %). The third decomposition stage continued with a weight loss of 30 % up to 500 °C. This process suggested the thermal decomposition of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate.

A strong absorbance band centred at 260 nm with high molar extinction coefficient could be attributed to π-π* type transition within protonated acridines. A series of bands centered at 347, 357, 379 and 397 nm could be attributed to the π→π* transitions within the btc3- ligands [27]. The maxima of absorption wavelengths with the molar extinction coefficients as well as the assignment of the absorption spectra are summarized in Table 3.

Fluorescence Emission

A number of polynuclear d10 transition metal complexes, such as Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers, exhibit interesting luminescence properties [28-30]. Fluorescent investigation of 1 was carried out in the solution and the solid phase at room temperature. As illustrated in Fig. 7a, upon a single-wavelength photo-excitation at 274 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of 1 in the solution phase shows three overlapping emission bands in the range of 380-650 nm (peak at 407, 431 and 455 nm), which is similar to the emission property of original acridine ligand in Fig. 7b. So the multiband emission of 1 could be assigned to the emission of the pure organic component [19]. Study of the photoluminescence properties of 1 in the solid state at room temperature is shown in Fig. 7c. Excitation at λex = 270 nm leads to a broad emission from 350 to 500 nm compared with the emission of 1 in the solution phase. This is presumably due to the combination of ion electronic state induced by strong face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between protonated cations and btc3- ligands as well as strong hydrogen bonding interactions in the solid phase [31, 32]. The multiband emissions are expected to be useful in designing luminescent devices.
